messages.content: Bola, I can't believe you were stupid enough to get caught.
Ada, I'm sorry. I didn't think they'd find out.
You're lucky my husband is out of town on business. I'll try to think of something to cover this up
Ada, who are you talking to?
Just a business call, dear.
Are you sure?
Yes, I'm sure.
Bola, we need to talk.
What is it?
You were seen with another woman.
It's not what it looks like.
What do you mean?
Kemi is my sister.
Your sister?
Yes, my sister. I was just helping her with something.
I see.
Ada, who is this man?
He's just an old friend.
I don't believe you.
Femi, what are you doing here?
Kemi? What are you doing here?
I'm sorry, Femi. I didn't mean for it to happen.
Can you tell me about your relationship with Bola?
He's just an old friend.
And yet, witnesses saw the two of you acting intimately.
It's not what it seems.
Can you elaborate?
Bola and I were having an affair.
And what about your husband, Femi?
Femi knew nothing about it.
Can you tell me about your relationship with Kemi?
Kemi is my mistress.
And yet, you were seen with another woman.
this story!
I'm sorry, Femi. I never meant to hurt you.
messages.emotion: sitting in living room with Femi and Bola

messages.content: How could you do this to me?
I don't know. I just couldn't help myself.
I'm sorry, Femi. I never meant to come between you and Ada.
I don't know what to say.
Femi, I'm sorry. I never meant for any of this to happen.
I can't believe this. My wife and my best friend were having an affair and my mistress is in love with me.
Femi, what's going on?
Chuka, my life is falling apart.
I'm sorry, Femi. I had no idea.
I've lost everything. My husband, my lover, my life.
Ada, we need to talk.
Femi, are you willing to forgive me?
I can't forget what you did, but I can forgive you.
Ada, I'm sorry.
Bola, I can't see you again.
Femi, I understand if you never want to see me again.
Kemi, I can't just forget about you.
Femi, Ada, Bola, Kemi, I know this is a difficult time for all of us, but I want you to know that I'm here for you.
Thank you, Chuka.
Hey, Tola. How have you been?
messages.emotion: BAYO stands nervously in front of TOLA, who sits on the couch, arms crossed.

messages.content: Fine, I suppose. What do you want, Bayo?
I just wanted to talk.
Alright, let's talk. What's on your mind?
I just wanted to apologize for how things ended between us.
Apologize? You don't think through things, Bayo. You let your pride cloud your judgement and react before you have had the time to process. That's why our relationship ended.
You see, this our little relationship is big sister-small brother relationship. You don't have what it takes to love me properly.
messages.emotion: She stands up, getting in Bayo's face

messages.content: You see them over there? They have what it takes. What you need is a big sister, not another girlfriend.
messages.emotion: She gestures to BOLU and KIYO

messages.content: [action]
messages.emotion: Bayo stands there looking sad and defeated.

I do take it seriously, but I just don't think it's going to be as bad as everyone is making it out to be.
Are you kidding me? The sea level is rising, and coastal cities like Lagos are going to be flooded. We need to start taking action now.
I understand your concern, but I've also seen reports that say the effects of global warming might not be as severe as we thought. We need to be careful not to jump to conclusions.
Nneka, the evidence is clear. The world is getting warmer, and the consequences are going to be catastrophic if we don't take action now.
I get it, Chukwu. But what can we do as individuals? We can recycle and reduce our carbon footprint, but that's not going to solve the problem.
Every little bit helps, Nneka. And if enough people take action, it will make a difference. We also need to advocate for more government policies that address the issue.
You're right. I'll start taking the issue more seriously and see what I can do to help.
That's all I can ask for. We need to work together to make a change.
Agreed. Let's do our part to protect our planet.
They sit in silence for a moment, contemplating the gravity of the situation
Hey, let's grab a drink. I know a great place near here that serves fresh coconut water.
Sounds good. I could use a drink after this discussion.
They get up from the bench and walk away, ready to take action on the issue of global warming
Three friends, TOLU, DAMI, and CHIDI, are catching up over coffee
Guys, do you remember that trip we took to Jos when we were kids?
Of course I do. That was one of the best trips of my life.
Yeah, it was so much fun. We went hiking, explored the city, and had the best food.
But do you remember what happened in that old abandoned school we stumbled upon?
The room falls silent as the memories of the traumatic incident come flooding back
The friends are standing in the dilapidated old school, reliving the traumatic event
I still can't believe what happened here.
I try to push it out of my mind, but it still haunts me.
We can't let it continue to control our lives. We need to talk about it and work through our trauma.
I don't know if I'm ready to face it. It's too painful.
We can do this together. We've always been there for each other.
Yeah, and we're stronger now than we were as kids. We can handle it.
The friends are back at the cafe, continuing their conversation
Okay, let's talk about it. But I need a drink first. (calls out) I need igbo and shayo!
I'll take one too.
messages.emotion: smiling at the attempt at humor

messages.content: They take a moment to compose themselves before delving into the painful memories
Let's start at the beginning. What do you remember about that day?
They spend the next hour talking through their memories and processing their emotions. It's a difficult but cathartic conversation
I feel so much lighter now that we've talked about it.
Me too. I can finally start to move on.
We're a strong team. We'll always have each other's backs.
They clink their drinks together in a toast to their friendship and resilience
I miss you, Chidinma
I miss you too, Taiwo. We had the worst fight ever.
I know. I'm so sorry. Can we talk and make up?
I would love that. Where are you right now?
I'm at home. How about you? ðŸ˜Ž
I'm at work, but I can take a break and call you.
They both pick up the phone and start talking, but the scene focuses on their text conversation
Your voice is so soothing. I've missed it so much.
Yours too, my love. I'm so glad we're talking again
I just want us to be happy again, Taiwo. What can we do to make that happen?
We just need to communicate better and listen to each other. And I promise to make it up to you, my love.
I would love that, Taiwo. Let's plan a date tonight and make up properly.
That sounds amazing, Chidinma. I can't wait to hold you and show you how much I love you.
I love you too, Taiwo. Let's make tonight unforgettable.
They both put down their phones with smiles on their faces,
Good morning, Ugochi! How was your sleep?
ðŸ˜Š
Good morning, Chinyere! My sleep was amazing, thanks for asking. How about you? ðŸ˜Š
I slept well, too. Dreaming about you always makes my nights better.
Aww, Chinyere. You always know how to make me smile.
What are you up to today?
Just running errands, but I'm free in the afternoon. Want to grab lunch together?
Absolutely! Where would you like to go?  ðŸ˜ ðŸ˜
How about that new Italian restaurant we've been wanting to try?
That sounds perfect, Ugochi. I can't wait
Me too, Chinyere. I can't wait to see you and share a meal.
They both put down their phones with smiles on their faces, looking forward to their lunch date
Banky, why aren't you home yet? I feel so lonely without you.
I'm sorry, my love. I had a meeting that went longer than expected. I'm on my way home now.
That's not good enough, Banky. This has been happening a lot lately. I feel like I'm always alone.
I understand how you feel, bby. But I promise, I'm working hard to make a better life for us.
But what good is a better life if we're not happy together? Love is kind, Banky. It's patient and it doesn't keep a record of wrongs.
I know the Bible, Susu. And I also know that I love you more than anything in this world.
I just want you to understand how I feel, Banky. I need you to be here for me.
I'm sorry, Adesua. I'll be home soon. I promise.  ðŸ™

haha
an interaction from season 5, episode 13
We're supposed to be honest.
I wish you could tell me, "I don't like your massages."
I don't like your massages.
See? It's no big deal.
But now you're crying!
I'm not crying about that. I'm crying about something at work.
My boyfriend said he didn't like my massages.
You don't have to be best at everything.
Oh, my God! You don't know me at all!
You give the worst massages in the world.
I'm crying here!
Look, hear me out.
You give the best bad-massages.
If anybody was looking for the best bad-massage...
...and they thought, "Who's the best?"
They'd have to go to you.
So you're saying that if there was an award...
...for the best bad-massage.... Who would get that?
It would be you!
You, Monica! And you'd get all the votes.
So they could call the award, "The Monica"?
Absolutely.
I suck!
Two young people, Kingsley (20s), and Chichi (20s), are at a party in Abuja. They are standing on opposite sides of the room, and their eyes meet.
quickly looks away, feeling shy.
notices his reaction and decides to make her move. She walks over to Kingsley and introduces herself.
Hey, I'm Chi. I don't think we've met before.
Hi, I'm Kingsley. Nice to meet you.
So, what brings you here?
Just hanging out with friends. How about you?
Same here. But I have to admit, I couldn't help but notice you from across the room. You have a great smile.
Thank you. You have a great smile too.
Thanks. So, Kingsley, do you dance?
I do, but I'm not that good.
Well, that's okay. I'm not that good either. Maybe we can dance together and make a fool of ourselves.
I'd like that.
Great. Let's go.
They walk to the dance floor and start dancing. As they dance, CHICHI subtly flirts with KINGSLEY, trying to get his attention.
You know, Kingsley, I think you're really cute.
Thanks, Chichi. You're really beautiful.
Aw, thank you.
They continue dancing, and KINGSLEY starts to pick up on CHICHI's flirting.
You know, Chichi, I have to admit something.
What's that?
I think you're flirting with me.
Me? Flirting? No way.
Yes way. And I have to say, I like it.
Well, I'm glad you do.
They continue dancing and flirting, and eventually exchange phone numbers.
Here, put your number in. I'd love to hang out with you again.
Sure. I'd like that too.
They exchange numbers, and the scene ends with them both smiling.
EMEKA (30s) and ADA (late 20s) are sitting across from each other at a restaurant. They are on a blind date, set up by their mutual friends.
So, Ada, do you always let your friends set you up on blind dates?
No, this is a first for me. But they say you're a great guy, so I had to give it a try.
Well, I hope I live up to their expectations.
So, Emeka, tell me about yourself. What do you do?
I work in the oil and gas industry. How about you?
I work in tech. I'm a software engineer.
Impressive. I'm not that tech-savvy. But I do like to keep up with current affairs. Did you hear about the latest fuel price hike?
Yes, it's crazy. The government keeps increasing the price of fuel, and the masses keep suffering. It's like they don't care about the common man.
I hear you. But have you seen the memes about it on Twitter?
Yes, I have. Nigerians are the kings and queens of memes. We can find humor in anything.
That's true. But speaking of Twitter, did you see that video of the traffic in Lagos?
Yes, it's insane. Lagos traffic is the worst. I don't know how people do it every day.
Well, it's part of the hustle. But I hear there are plans to build more roads and bridges to ease the traffic.
Yeah, I heard about that too. But I hope they don't just build roads for the rich areas. They should also build for the poor areas.
Definitely. Inequality is a big problem in Nigeria. But speaking of poor areas, have you been to Ajegunle?
No, I haven't. Why?
You should go. It's a tough place, but the people there are some of the most resilient and resourceful I've ever met.
I'll definitely add it to my to-do list. And speaking of to-do lists, I'm really enjoying this date.
Me too. I think our friends did a good job setting us up.
Agreed. So, Emeka, can I see you again after this?
Absolutely. I was hoping you'd ask.
They finish their meal, pay the bill, and leave the restaurant.
Kemi and Tunde, two highly educated lawyers, sit at a table in the library with a stack of books and papers in front of them. They appear deep in conversation.
I just don't understand why we keep going through this same cycle every four years. The people in power keep getting richer, and the rest of us keep getting poorer.
It's a complex problem, but one of the major issues is the lack of money in circulation. The government keeps printing more and more, which leads to inflation and ultimately devalues our currency.
Yes, and the increased fuel prices are making matters even worse. It's affecting everyone, from the poor to the rich.
The electoral process is also a mess. There's so much lawlessness and corruption, it's hard to have faith in the system.
And the youth, they are the ones who suffer the most. They're the most affected by unemployment, poor education, and lack of opportunities.
It's a sad state of affairs. But there is hope. Have you heard about the presidential candidate, Peter Obi? He has a solid track record and a reputation for being a reformer.
Yes, I've heard about him, but what about Sowore? He has a strong anti-corruption platform and has been an activist for years.
But does he have the experience to lead a country? We need someone who can balance both.
But we also need someone who can inspire and mobilize the youth. They are the future of this country.
That's a good point. I think we need to be more informed about the candidates and their policies before we make a decision.
As Kemi and Tunde continue their discussion, a third lawyer, Akin, approaches their table and pulls up a chair.
Mind if I join you guys? I couldn't help but overhear your conversation, and I have some thoughts on the matter.
Please, be our guest.
Thanks. I think we're all in agreement that the electoral process needs a major overhaul. But we also need to address the root cause of the problem: corruption.
Easier said than done. Corruption is so deeply ingrained in our society that it's almost become a way of life.
But it doesn't have to be that way. We need leaders who are willing to take a stand and fight for what's right.
That's true, but we also need to hold our leaders accountable. We can't just vote and then forget about them for the next four years.
Yes, we need to be more engaged and proactive in the political process. It's not just about who we vote for, but what we do after the election.
The three lawyers continue their debate, making strong points for their respective candidates and discussing potential solutions to the problems facing the country.
As the conversation winds down, Kemi and Tunde exchange numbers with Akin and agree to continue their discussion at a later date.
I'm glad we could have this conversation. It's important to have a space to discuss these issues.
Absolutely

sitting on a bench, each with a bottle of beer in his hand. They all appear to be in their 50s, well dressed, and have serious expressions on their faces. They are all engaged in a heated debate about the best economic system for Nigeria.
I think we should adopt socialism. It's the only way to reduce inequality and ensure that everyone has access to basic necessities.
Nonsense! Capitalism is the only system that can promote economic growth and create wealth.
You're both wrong. We need a hybrid system that takes the best elements of both socialism and capitalism.
I disagree. We need to focus on building a strong and effective government that can regulate the economy and ensure that everyone benefits.
But a strong government is only possible under socialism. Capitalism only benefits the rich.
But under capitalism, anyone can become rich if they work hard and smart.
But capitalism also leads to extreme inequality and exploitation.
And socialism leads to laziness and dependence on the government.
That's not true. Socialism promotes a sense of community and cooperation.
But it also stifles innovation and creativity.
And capitalism leads to a dog-eat-dog mentality that destroys social cohesion.
But socialism leads to government bureaucracy and inefficiency.
And capitalism leads to corporate greed and environmental destruction.
But socialism leads to government corruption and lack of accountability.
And capitalism leads to financial instability and boom-and-bust cycles.
But socialism leads to a lack of incentives and motivation.
The argument goes back and forth for a while, with each person making valid points and counterarguments. But then something unexpected happens.
You know what? Maybe we should just adopt a feudal system. I can be the king, Bola can be my chief adviser, Ekene can be the high priest, and Tunde can be the court jester.
Everyone laughs at Olu's joke, and the tension is broken. They continue the debate, but with a more lighthearted tone.
I don't think I want to be your adviser. I prefer to be the king myself.
And I don't think I want to be the high priest. I prefer to be the village doctor.
And I don't think I want to be the court jester. I prefer to be the royal chef.
Fine, we'll have a democracy. We'll each have a vote, and the majority wins.
Agreed
Sounds good to me.
As long as there's good food, I'm in.

The conversation continues, but now with a more collaborative and respectful tone. They start to brainstorm ideas for how to improve the Nigerian economy, and they even come up with some practical solutions.
Suddenly, their wives call out to them from a nearby table, telling them that the food is ready. The men stand up, finish their drinks, and head over to the table.
Well, I guess we'll have to continue this debate another day.
Ok, see you guys later
We see two teenage girls, Chidinma and Zainab, sitting on their bunks, talking.
I swear, Zainab, that boy is the finest boy in this school.
Ha! Abeg, which one? You no see Desmond wey come from Lagos? That boy is fresh.
I don't know, o. Something about the way Obinna carries himself, he's just different.
Ehen! I sabi that kind thing. But me, I like boys wey get body. That's why I dey eye Jide.
Jide? That one wey always dey read book? Abeg, park well.
No be so, Chidinma. That boy sabi. He get sense pass all these boys wey dey form swag.
Ehn, you and your book-loving boys. Me, I like my man fine, tall, and with plenty swag.
You dey fall my hand, Chidinma. I no know why you go like all these unserious boys.
Unserious kwa? Obinna is not unserious o. He get sense, e sabi book, and he sabi chop life.
Chop life? I hope you no dey fall for all these lies boys dey tell us. No be chop life wey go make you get A for your exams.
But you too dey serious na. Life no go sweet if you no chop am small. And Obinna sabi enjoyment.
Enjoyment how? You no dey shame? You no see the way him dey follow all these girls wey no dey wear pant?
Ehen? Na me you dey talk to like that? Abeg, leave me and my Obinna alone.
No vex, Chidinma. I dey talk am for your own good. You no go want make all these boys just dey use you play.
Who tell you say I no sabi hold my own?
I just dey talk. You know I like you as you dey
They both laugh.
an older girl, FUNMI, enters the dormitory.
Una still dey talk? Abeg, make una leave all these boys. Una be senior girls now, una suppose sabi say all this play play go end for school gate
Abeg, Funmi. No be your mate wey we dey talk about.
You sef no go understand.
Understand wetin? Una never reach where man matter suppose dey important for una life.
Abeg, abeg, abeg. Make we hear word
Funmi. You too dey somehow
I no dey shakara, o. I just dey try make una see the bigger picture. Love no be everything for this life.
We know, Funmi. But e no go kill us to like person na. small small.
Abi o!
Tunji and Lola sit close to each other on a sofa. There's a spark in their eyes and a palpable attraction between them.
You know you're the most beautiful woman I've ever met.
You're just trying to flatter me.
No, I mean it. There's something special about you.
Thanks, Tunji.
Tunji leans in to kiss Lola, but she pulls back.
I can't do this. I'm engaged to Tade.
I know, but I can't help how I feel.
I wish things were different.
Tunji sits at his desk, scrolling through his phone. His colleague, Funmi, walks in.
Hey, Tunji. Have you seen Tade around?
Why do you need to see him?
Oh, we have a meeting later.
Right
Funmi exits, and Tunji's phone vibrates. It's a message from Lola: "Can we meet?"
Lola and Tunji sit across from each other, hands intertwined.
I can't stop thinking about you.
I know, Lola. But we can't keep doing this.
I'm sorry. I just can't help the way I feel.
I understand.
They share a sad smile, knowing what they have to do.
Tade sits at his desk, talking on the phone.
I'll be home soon, babe. I have a surprise for you.
Tunji walks in, looking nervous.
Tunji! What brings you here?
Tade, I have to tell you something.
What is it?
I'm in love with Lola.
Tade looks at Tunji, his expression changing from concern to anger.
You're what?!
I'm sorry, man. I didn't mean for it to happen.
Tade stands up, towering over Tunji.
Get out of my office!
Tunji exits, dejected.
As he walks down the hallway, his phone rings. It's Lola.
Tunji, Tade knows.
Tunji stops in his tracks, realizing the depth of the trouble he's in.
Jessica and Lisa sit across from each other, sipping their lattes.
OMG! You didn't tell me you were married!
What? I'm not married.
But I saw the pictures on your Instagram with the guy in the suit and the ring on your finger!
Oh, that's just my friend John. We went to a wedding together and he let me wear his ring as a joke.
Oh, thank goodness! I was worried I had missed something big.
You know me, I'll be sure to tell you when I meet the love of my life.
You better! So, what's new with you?
Well, actually, I've been having some problems with my boyfriend.
What kind of problems?
It's just that he's been so distant lately, and I don't know what's going on. I've tried talking to him about it, but he always shuts me down.
I'm so sorry, that sounds really tough.
messages.emotion: putting a hand on Lisa's arm

messages.content: Thanks. I just don't know what to do.
Well, first things first, we're going to finish our lattes and then we're going to come up with a plan to get to the bottom of this. Sound good?
Sounds good to me.
Amara and Chinasa sit across from each other on a sofa, sipping tea.
I never knew marriage was like this!
What do you mean?
It's just so different from what I expected. It's like a whole new world.
I know what you mean. How's your husband doing?
He's doing great. He's such a wonderful man. I feel so lucky to have him.
That's great to hear. So, what's been the biggest surprise for you so far?
Honestly, just how much work it is. I knew it would be hard, but I didn't realize just how much effort it takes to make a marriage work.
Yeah, I can imagine. What kind of things are you finding challenging?
Well, just little things like compromise and communication. It's not always easy to put someone else's needs before your own.
I hear you. But it's all worth it in the end, right?
Definitely. I love being married. It's the best decision I've ever made.
I'm so happy for you. And I know you'll make it work, no matter what challenges come your way.
Thanks, Chinasa. I appreciate your support.
Bose and Funke sit across from each other on a sofa, sipping tea.
He cheated on me!
What? Who did?
My husband! I just found out he's been seeing another woman.
Oh no, I'm so sorry to hear that. How did you find out?
I saw a message on his phone. They've been seeing each other for months.
That's terrible. How could he do that to you?
I don't know. I thought we were happy. But now I feel like I don't even know him.
I can't imagine what you're going through. But you deserve better than that. You don't have to put up with his infidelity.
I know. I just don't know what to do next.
Well, the first step is to talk to him. Find out what's been going on and why he did it. Then you can decide whether or not to forgive him.
I don't know if I can do that.
It's okay to take some time to think about it. Just remember that you deserve to be with someone who loves and respects you.
Thanks, Funke. I appreciate your advice.
Anytime, Bose. I'm here for you.
Akwasi and Kojo sit on armchairs, sipping tea and chatting.
Remember the days of Kwame Nkrumah and Obafemi Awolowo? Those were the days of true leaders.
Yes, those were the days. The youth were so socially inclined, always talking about politics and the future of the country.
Nowadays, all the youth seem to care about are frivolities like house parties and social media.
It's a shame. Our country is on a decline and they don't seem to care.
We need to motivate the youth to get involved and make a difference. We can't just sit back and watch our country crumble.
But how do we do that? How do we get them interested in something other than partying and entertainment?

We need to show them the importance of being socially responsible. We need to encourage them to volunteer and get involved in their communities. We need to help them see that their actions can make a difference.
That's a good point. We need to inspire them to be the change they want to see in the world.
Exactly. We might be old, but we still have a lot to offer. We can help guide the youth and motivate them to create a better future for themselves and for our country.
You're right. We may be old, but we're not done yet.
Tamika and Marcus sit at a table, sipping coffee and chatting.
Monica is going to divorce Chandler! Can you imagine marrying someone whose name is Bing? Hahaha!
What?! They're getting divorced? I thought they were perfect for each other.
Apparently, Chandler cheated on her.
Man, that sucks. Chandler always seemed like a good guy.
Yeah, a good guy with a terrible name.
What's wrong with his name? Chandler Bing has a nice ring to it.
It sounds like a search engine. "Just Bing it!"
Okay, I'll give you that one. But still, it's not like he chose his own name.
Yeah, but he chose to marry someone named Monica Geller. She sounds like a cartoon character.
Monica Geller? I never thought of it like that. But hey, at least their names are memorable.
Memorable for all the wrong reasons.
Alright, what about your name, Tamika?
What about it?
It's a nice name, but it's not exactly common.
So? It's unique, just like me.
Yeah, but you know what they say about unique names. They're like a box of chocolates.
Oh, please. Don't bring Forrest Gump into this.
I had to. But seriously, Chandler Bing and Monica Geller are iconic names. They're part of pop culture history.
Okay, fine. But just because they're iconic doesn't mean they're good names.
I guess we'll just have to agree to disagree.
Agreed
Jason! I can't believe it's you!
Hey, Jess. It's been a while.
So, how have you been?
Good, good. Just busy with work and stuff. You?
Same here. I actually just started a new job a few months ago. It's been really challenging but also rewarding.
That's great to hear. What else is new with you?
Well, I've been dating this guy for a little while now. His name is Alex and he's really sweet.
That's awesome, Jess. I'm happy for you.
What about you? Are you seeing anyone?
No, not at the moment. I've been on a few dates here and there, but nothing serious.
Well, I'm sure there are plenty of girls who would love to go out with you.
Hey, do you remember that night we went camping in the woods?
Of course. That was such a great time.
Yeah, it was. I still think about it sometimes.
Me too.
You know, it's funny. Even though we haven't talked in years, it's like no time has passed at all.
Yeah, it is. I've missed you, Jess.
I've missed you too.
Hey there beautiful. How's your day going?
Hi Olu, my day is good. Just trying to stay productive. How about you?
Same here, but I can't stop thinking about you. You were on my mind all day.
Oh really? And why is that?
Because you're amazing, Tina. I can't get enough of your beautiful smile and your sharp mind.
You always know how to make me feel special, Olu.
That's because you are special to me. I can't stop thinking about the way your eyes light up when you talk about your passions. You're so intelligent and driven, it's really inspiring.
You're making me blush, Olu. I never knew you saw me that way.
How could I not? You're the most beautiful and captivating woman I've ever met. And the more I get to know you, the more I'm drawn to you.
You have a way with words, Olu. I have to admit, I've been thinking about you a lot too.
Is that so? What have you been thinking about?
Oh, just how handsome and charming you are. And how much I enjoy our conversations.
You're too kind, Tina. But I have to say, I'm really looking forward to seeing you again. I have this overwhelming urge to kiss you.
Oh really? Well, maybe we can arrange that soon. I have a feeling our chemistry will be amazing.
I have no doubt about that. You're the missing piece in my life, Tina. And I can't wait to explore everything we can be together.
I feel the same way, Olu. Let's see where this goes.

Three women, ZARA (35), ADAORA (34), and NIA (33) sit on a couch, surrounded by wedding magazines and decorations. Zara is frantically making a list while Adaora and Nia admire a picture of their friend, Amara, and her fiancÃ©.
I'm making a list of all the things that can go wrong on Amara's big day. I want to be prepared for any disaster.
Oh Zara, always the realist. You need to relax and have faith that everything will work out.
She's right, Zara. Amara is in good hands with her fiancÃ©. They're perfect for each other.
I know, I just want everything to be perfect for her. She deserves the best.
And we'll make sure it is. We'll all pitch in and help with the planning and organization.
Yes, and we'll be there to support her on the big day. That's what friends are for.
You're right. I'm so happy for Amara and her fiancÃ©. They make such a great couple, and they're so in love.
It's infectious, isn't it? I feel like their love is rubbing off on all of us.
Definitely. I feel like I'm in a romantic movie whenever I'm around them.
Me too. They give me hope that true love really does exist.
It does. And it's all around us, if we're open to it.
Yes, we just have to be patient and trust that it will come to us when the time is right.
I believe that. And I'm so grateful for both of you. You're such amazing friends, and I don't know what I would do without you.
Same here, Zara. We're in this together, and we'll be there for each other no matter what.
Always and forever.
the story of Lazarus, what do we think it means?
Well, for me, it's a story of hope. It shows that even when things seem impossible, Jesus can still bring life out of death.
Yes, and it also shows the power of faith. Martha and Mary believed that Jesus could heal their brother, and he did.
I agree, and it also shows Jesus' love for his friends. He wept when he saw Mary and Martha grieving, even though he knew he was going to raise Lazarus.
But, what about the symbolism of the four days Lazarus was in the tomb? Does that have any significance?

Actually, I think it does. In Jewish culture, it was believed that the soul of a person would linger around the body for three days after death, hoping to re-enter it. But on the fourth day, the soul would depart, and the person would truly be dead.
Wow, I never knew that. So, maybe the four days represent the point of no return, the point where even the soul has given up hope.
And, it shows the power of Jesus to bring life even from the point of no return.
That's a great point. And what about the fact that Lazarus was bound in grave clothes?
I think it represents the bondage of sin and death. Jesus had to remove the grave clothes to set Lazarus free.
Yes, and it shows that Jesus has the power to break any chains that bind us, even the chains of sin and death.
I also think it shows that sometimes we need the help of others to be set free. Jesus asked the people around him to help remove the grave clothes.
This is such a powerful story. I think we could go on talking about it for hours.
But, we've already been talking for ten minutes.
Everyone laughs.
We should probably wrap it up. But, let's keep studying and learning from the stories of Jesus.
Amen to that.
Brothers and sisters, the cross is the most important symbol of our faith. It is through the cross that we are saved.
Yes, Bukola is right. The cross represents the ultimate sacrifice that Jesus made for our sins.
It's amazing to think that one man's death could have such a profound impact on the world.
But why the cross? Why did Jesus have to die in such a painful way?
The cross symbolizes the weight of our sins. Jesus took on the burden of our sins so that we could be saved.
And the cross is also a symbol of victory over death. Jesus died on the cross, but He rose from the dead and conquered death.
That's why the cross is so powerful. It represents both the sacrifice and the victory of Jesus.
It's interesting to think about how the cross is used in our everyday lives. We see it on buildings and jewelry, but sometimes I wonder if we truly understand its significance.
That's a good point, Amina. We need to remember that the cross is not just a symbol, but a reminder of the love and sacrifice of Jesus.
And it's not just about Jesus' sacrifice, but also about our own sacrifice. Jesus calls us to take up our cross and follow Him.
Yes, we must be willing to die to ourselves and our own desires and follow Jesus, just as He died on the cross for us.
And the cross is also a symbol of unity. It brings us together as brothers and sisters in Christ.
That's right. No matter our differences, we are all united by the cross and our belief in Jesus.
I think the cross is also a symbol of hope. It reminds us that no matter what we're going through, we have hope in Jesus and His promise of eternal life.
Exactly. The cross is a symbol of new life and a fresh start. Through Jesus, we can be made new and have a new beginning.
Let us pray and thank God for the cross, and for the sacrifice and victory of Jesus.
